rationale: Giuseppe Maria Foppa is indeed a librettist. He wrote the libretto for Il signor Bruschino, an opera by Gioacchino Rossini. Therefore, the statement is true.

world: librettist: author of the libretto (words) of an opera, operetta, oratorio or cantata, or of the book of a musical.
rationale: The statement "librettist(Falstaff, Arrigo Boito)" asserts that Arrigo Boito is the librettist for the opera "Falstaff." Based on the definition provided, this statement is true. Arrigo Boito did indeed write the libretto for the opera "Falstaff."

world: librettist: author of the libretto (words) of an opera, operetta, oratorio or cantata, or of the book of a musical.
rationale: Maurice Maeterlinck is known to have written librettos for various operas and theatrical works. One of his most famous works in this genre is "Herzgewächse" (Puppet Play), which was later adapted into an opera by Debussy with the same name. Therefore, the statement "librettist(Herzgewächse, Maurice Maeterlinck)" is true.

world: librettist: author of the libretto (words) of an opera, operetta, oratorio or cantata, or of the book of a musical.
rationale: Metastasio is known to be a librettist. The statement "librettist(Il re pastore, Pietro Metastasio)" is true because Pietro Metastasio wrote the libretto for Il re pastore.

world: librettist: author of the libretto (words) of an opera, operetta, oratorio or cantata, or of the book of a musical.
rationale: John Newton was indeed the author of the words to the hymn "Amazing Grace." However, the statement provided refers to him as a librettist, which is typically used to describe someone who writes the words for an opera, operetta, oratorio, or cantata, or the book of a musical. Since "Amazing Grace" is not an opera, operetta, oratorio, cantata, or musical, John Newton cannot be considered a librettist for "Amazing Grace."
